title: BBC Rogue Traders steal their own cars back from 'secure' airport parking firm
text:
The BBC's Rogue Traders team stole their own cars back from a 'secure' airport parking firm that leaves its customers' vehicles in a muddy field with their keys tossed in the boot.

An investigation by the consumer rights series will air tonight and shows how price comparison websites claim that Park Direct Gatwick Ltd offers CCTV, security and a gated entrance with a security fence protect cars left with them.

But the Watchdog Live show's host, Matt Allwright, revealed to Mirror Online ahead of tonight's broadcast that he 'couldn't believe' how easy it was to snatch their cars.

He said: 'It's staggering that you can hand your keys to a stranger only to find it parked in a muddy field, the keys accessible and sometimes even damaged while you're on holiday.

Pictured: A Rogue Trader crew member makes off with the car after leaving vehicles with the firm near Gatwick Airport

Matt Allwright (pictured) says he couldn't believe how easy it was to steal back the vehicles

'We'd known for some time that the airport parking industry had some rogues, but never dreamt we would be able to take our own vehicle back so easily.'

The firm - which is based around London Gatwick airport - maintains that it offered secure bases with customers' keys attended to at all times.

The BBC investigation was launched after the show received complaints about the company.

A whistleblower confirmed to the team that cars are left in fields, the Rogue Traders team claims.

Pictured: The field in which Rogue Traders discovered their cars had been left despite third party websites claiming the firm uses secure sites

Four customers met with the crew. One, named Jo, said when she went to Florida she came back to find paintwork coming off the bonnet.

She says she had to fork out more than £1,000 and that the company only offered her £100.

The customer said she took the firm to court to get a County Court Judgement but says she hasn't seen any money yet.

Rogue Traders booked two cars in with Park Direct Gatwick. They found both in a field, with the keys in the boot of another vehicle - alongside hundreds of other car keys.

Park Direct Gatwick disputes the findings of the episode, which airs at 8pm on BBC One.

A spokesperson said that keys were attended and secured at all times and added it does have control of third party websites.

They said that terms and conditions on how to raise complaints or claim for damages.
description: The show's Matt Allwright has revealed that the firm, based near Gatwick Airport, left hundreds of sets of keys in a boot after the team booked in two vehicles when they received complaints.
